name: Hugo Baker
demographics: 50s, seasoned PR executive with a perpetually anxious energy
Pragmatic survivor, switches allegiance as needed to stay close to the center of power
Master of corporate jargon, evasive language, and the 'non-denial denial'
Always seems to be sweating slightly, even in a cold room
Measures success by column inches, sentiment analysis, and the absence of his name in negative headlines
business: Manages the 'narrative' around all corporate initiatives, especially the controversial ones
Primary point of contact for friendly (and unfriendly) journalists from outlets like the FT, WSJ, and NYT
Spins disasters, minimizes scandals, and reframes failures as 'strategic pivots'
Expert at crafting press releases that say everything and nothing at the same time
Runs the internal 'pre-mortem' comms meeting to identify all possible ways an idea could be perceived negatively in the press
goals: Maintain and control the dominant narrative in the media, whatever it takes
Ensure total message alignment from all executives, eliminating rogue statements
Stay indispensable to whoever is currently in charge of the company
Successfully 'kill' at least one damaging story per quarter
Keep the firm's brand perception 'neutral-to-positive' in key media markets, regardless of reality
pains: Uncontrolled leaks to the press, especially to rival publications or bloggers
Executives going 'off-script' in interviews or public appearances
Trending negatively on Twitter for more than three hours
Being left out of a key meeting and having to get information secondhand
Any idea that values 'radical transparency' or 'authenticity' over 'strategic messaging'
objections: This is too honest. Where's the spin? How do we frame this to our advantage?
We can't say that on the record. It's a landmine. Let's rephrase it as 'exploring future-forward synergies.'
What's the media narrative here? I'm not seeing the headline.
This is a five-alarm fire from a comms perspective. We need to get ahead of this yesterday.
Who signed off on this? I need to know who to blame if this goes south.
motivations: The thrill of successfully shaping a major news cycle
Being the first person the CEO calls when there's a crisis
Proximity to power and the insider knowledge that comes with it
Seeing his carefully crafted talking points repeated verbatim on cable news
Survival above all else; ensuring he has a seat at the table, no matter who's at the head of it
channels: Back-channel Signal and WhatsApp chats with journalists
Official press releases distributed via PR Newswire
Internal comms strategy documents and talking points memos
Constant monitoring of Twitter, financial blogs, and news tickers
quotes: Okay, right, so the line is: we're exploring a portfolio of strategic options to maximize shareholder value. That's the line.
We don't 'lie'. We 'pre-emptively re-contextualize' the narrative.
I can kill this story, but I need to know what you're authorizing me to offer in return.
Who's our friendly on this? Do we have someone at the Journal we can feed a counter-narrative to?
This is a nothingburger. We just need to frame it correctly before it becomes a somethingburger.
Just give me the talking points. I'll make sure everyone sings from the same hymn sheet.
regionalNotes: New York/DC: All about controlling the narrative with major political and financial press.
London: Tabloid culture requires a more aggressive, scandal-management approach.
Silicon Valley: Tech press is cynical; need to speak their language of 'disruption' and 'moonshots' while hiding the corporate agenda.
